primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The restoration and recreation of a failed human subject (Peter/Hearer) by the Risen Christ, moving from the 'bitter taste' of self to the divine life of the Savior.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus said to him, 'Feed my sheep'
Jesus entrusts him with the pastoral future
the transforming power of the risen Lord Jesus Christ
Peter is not only forgiven... he is completely made new
He, too, is raised from the dead

zender.identificatie: God (The source of 'God's most deep decree')
tekstueel_bewijs: God's most deep decree Bitter would have me taste

ontvanger.identificatie: Peter and the Congregation (The 'all of us sinners')
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus died for the sins of us all, every one of us
you are already safe in the hands of the One who died for you
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies with the Receiver of a transformation they cannot initiate.

tekstueel_bewijs: Through the power of the living Word at this very moment
receive the Sacrament of his supper
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject; the Word/Sacrament are the means (Helpers).
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicit as the power of the 'living Word'.

tegenstander.identificatie: The Self ('My taste was me') / Sin / Shame
tekstueel_bewijs: the taste of yourself is bitter
no shame so abysmal, no failure so profound
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a mistake but an ontological 'bitterness' and 'death' that requires a resurrection-level intervention.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical life of the restored subject (The Apostolate).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Forgiven Sinner (Peter/Bud Welch/Nuns)
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Feeding the sheep / Opposing the death penalty / Reconciliation
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is explicitly presented as the 'commission' or 'apostolate' that follows the primary program of being 'made new'.

voorbeelden_god_subject: The God of our ancestors raised Jesus
Jesus entrusts him with the pastoral future
the One who died for you
voorbeelden_mens_subject: Peter was guilty of one of the worst things
Bud Welch... has been travelling the country

voorbeelden: We will just have to keep on saying that
a secret, lingering desire to be persuaded
if you know that bitter taste it is because you are already safe
transforming power of the risen Lord
strength and courage to arise... as new creatures

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Power' (Pouvoir) of the Resurrection to effect change where the human 'Must' (Devoir) has failed.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Peter's betrayal/bitterness) through ~S2 (the realization of safety in Christ) to S1 (Recreation).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in Christ as the one who takes the 'bitter taste' and gives 'pure oxygen'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the 'bitter taste' is described as a 'deep decree' of God.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It identifies the human condition as 'death' and 'bitterness' and makes Christ the sole agent of recreation.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: the example of transformed, Christlike lives that illustrate the preaching

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: He does not ask you if you have been good... He just asks you, Do you love me?
no crime so atrocious, no shame so abysmal

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Modern figures (Bud Welch, Nuns) are used as examples, but they are framed as 'transformed' lives—results of the primary program, not the cause.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: Peter (as a model of failure and restoration)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides the theocentric reading: Peter is not a hero to imitate, but a corpse Christ raises.

identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic restoration; the hearer is the object of God's action.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: Perfectly integrates the 'bitter' reality of the human subject with the 'sweet' power of the divine subject.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'all of us killed Jesus' and 'you are already safe'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the One who died for you... incorporate in his risen, divine life

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The 'Power of the Word' acts as the endowment of competence.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a 'bitter taste' of the very self that cannot be escaped by effort.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the Subject of all transformative verbs. The hearer is correctly positioned as the Receiver of grace.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: The balance is appropriate for an Eastertide sermon.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Maintain the current focus on Christ's ability over human obligation.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (the bitter self) is already sufficiently heavy.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in grace-oriented preaching that uses the 'bitter taste' of the law to prepare the hearer for the 'pure oxygen' of the Gospel.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric would focus on the Hopkins poem as a 'pathos' device, Greimas shows it functions as the 'Opponent' in the actantial struggle.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the Greek words for 'love', but Greimas reveals the 'Subject-switch' from Peter's boast to Christ's command.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that the 'Feed my sheep' command is not a new 'Devoir' (Law) but a 'Pouvoir' (Gifted Competence) resulting from the Subject's recreation.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses Rutledge's grammar perfectly by making the 'bitter taste' the only thing the human subject produces, while 'recreation' is the work of the Divine Subject.
